title: 113_hr4065
content: The Act may be cited as the "Smartphone Theft Prevention Act". Congress finds that mobile device theft costs consumers $30 billion annually, with 1 in 3 robberies involving mobile device theft. Efforts have been made by carriers, manufacturers, law enforcement, and the FCC to address this issue, but more action is needed. Consumers deserve the most secure technology to protect their information, as technological protections continue to advance and benefit the economy. The wireless industry should collaborate with law enforcement to educate consumers on security tools and promote safety. The mobile device industry, law enforcement, and consumer advocates should proactively develop solutions to protect consumers, drive innovation, and deter theft. SEC. 3. FUNCTION FOR STOLEN MOBILE DEVICES. Amends the Communications Act of 1934 to include a new section addressing stolen mobile devices. In this section, the term 'account holder' for a mobile device refers to the person holding the account for commercial mobile service, including authorized persons. The term 'commercial mobile data service' is defined as per the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012. The Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 defines terms like 'commercial mobile service' and 'mobile device'. Providers of these services must offer a function on the device for the account holder's exclusive use, allowing remote capabilities. The Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012 requires providers of commercial mobile services to offer remote capabilities on mobile devices for account holders, including the ability to delete all account-related information, render the device inoperable on any network globally, and prevent the device from being accessed. The Act requires mobile service providers to offer remote capabilities on devices, including preventing reactivation without authorization and reversing actions if the device is recovered. The Act mandates that mobile devices must have remote capabilities for account holder recovery, including preventing unauthorized reactivation and reversing actions. Manufacturing or importing mobile devices for sale must comply with specific standards to enable these functions. The Act mandates remote capabilities for account holder recovery on mobile devices, including preventing unauthorized reactivation and reversing actions. Providers of commercial mobile services can be exempt from certain requirements if they offer technology on the device that achieves the same function. Manufacturers and importers may also be exempt from specific standards for devices manufactured or imported in the United States. The Act requires remote capabilities for account holder recovery on mobile devices, with exemptions for providers of commercial mobile services offering equivalent technology on the device. Manufacturers and importers in the United States may also be exempt from specific standards. The Act mandates remote recovery capabilities for account holders on mobile devices, exempting providers of commercial mobile services from charging fees for certain functions. Any person found to have violated specific sections of the Act will be liable to the United States for a forfeiture penalty determined by the Commission. This penalty is in addition to any other penalties outlined in the Act. Manufacturers of mobile devices and providers of commercial mobile services are not prohibited from certain actions by this section. The term "mobile device" is defined in section 343 of the Communications Act of 1934. This section applies to mobile devices manufactured in the United States after January 1, 2015. The Federal Communications Commission may grant compliance extensions to individuals subject to requirements under section 343(b) of the Communications Act of 1934, allowing more time for compliance if needed.
